# Marquardt & Tertytchnaya: _Sensitive Questions, Mode_

## Marquardt & Tertytchnaya: _Sensitive Questions, Mode_

\large
Sensitive questions \newline \pause 
\quad $\rightsquigarrow$ how R's report? \newline \pause 
\quad $\rightsquigarrow$ social desirability bias
\pause 

_Social desirability bias_ in surveys:
\pause 

$$S(x) = Pr(Z_{i, J+1}(0) = 1 | X_i = x) - Pr(Z^*_{i, J+1} = 1 | X_i = x)$$

\pause 

(First term: shown control, then asked _directly_)

[@blaima12]

***

\large
The difference between list estimate and direct question:

```{r echo=FALSE}
img <- readPNG("../ci-exp-essex-2025/notes/figs/05-list-race-socbias.png")
grid.raster(img)
```

***

\Large

But, Marquardt & Tertytchnaya highlights that there may be 

* $S_{\text{face-to-face}}(x)$
* $S_{\text{online}}(x)$

\pause 

And also, 

* differences in lists  
    (face-to-face v. online)
* differences in direct questions  
    (face-to-face v. online)

\pause 
Marquardt & Tertytchnaya looks at all of these potential differences!

## Some Issues

\large

>- Sampling
>    - Frames? Estimands?
>    - Age!
>- Different responses to modes -- reasons other than privacy/anonymity? 
>- Privacy/anonymity
>- Multiple comparisons?
>- Timing (p. 19)
>    - What happens in these months?
>    - All pre-/post-US election or transition?
>    - Different true levels of support in Nov/Jan?  
>- Are people shown several experiments?  
(p. 24 tables)
>- The non-privacy of lists  
(floors and ceilings, Table 11)

## Solutions

\large 

>- How to get around sampling/participation differences?

\pause 

Experiment: Recruit partcipants willing to do _either_ face-to-face or online, then randomise to mode.

\pause 

All statements about the "effect" of mode assume this?
\pause 

![](figs/991-marter-table.png){fig-align="center" height=35%}

\pause 

>- Region intercepts, not "effects"
